No changes since last entry. https://archive.ph/RJkd5  - A maximum of 10 people can be gathered indoors and 20 outdoors.  - In bars and restaurants, there can also be a maximum of 10 people per table indoors and  20 outside.  - The opening hours of bars, restaurants, cafes and pubs are until 3 in the morning.  - Premises that offer meals for social celebrations can accommodate a maximum of  50 people indoors and 120 outdoors.  - Capacity can be increased up to 100%, if all attendees are immunized or have a negative diagnostic test.

New rules apply in order to access Andorra from outside the EU or similar (e.g. United Kingdom), that you must have proof of either a vaccination certificate - a complete series received more than 14 days ago - recovery from the disease - has passed the COVID in the last 6 months - or a PCR / TMA test with a negative result performed in the last 72 hours before entering the Principality. The document must be carried to show it to the public authorities if they so request. In the event that the authorities detect the entry of people from outside the EU or similar and who do not have the aforementioned documentation, they must carry out a mandatory preventive confinement of 14 days, which may be reduced to 10 if they are made a diagnostic test to detect COVID-19. https://archive.vn/ua9Hj

The following expenses can be funded through the government program:   a) Salary  b) Financial liabilities arising from credit operations with Andorran banks.  c) Investments in the adaptation of establishments for the attention of the public to adapt to the sanitary requirements derived from the sanitary emergency situation caused by the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2.  d) Expenses for the supply of running water, electricity, telephony and heating.  e) Rental costs of commercial premises.  f) Fees for leasing operations (financial leasing) duly formalized.    https://archive.vn/MoxiC

From 18th Oct on, face masks are not required on the street or in outdoor spaces in Andorra. However, if it is not possible to respect physical distancing or a crowd forms, people are requested to wear them. Masks are still compulsory indoors for people over the age of 8, and are recommended for everyone over the age of 6. https://archive.vn/eMANS

On October 14th, 2021, the Corona Commission classifies all of Austria as high risk. The federal states of Carinthia, Lower Austria, Upper Austria and Styria are also rated as having a high risk. Burgenland as well as Tyrol, Vorarlberg and Vienna are rated with medium risk. Salzburg is classified as very high risk.    The classification for the education sector is still risk level I for Vorarlberg and risk level II for all other federal states.     Source: https://archive.vn/C5hBO#selection-543.0-563.129 [Corona traffic light map]

"From week 38, the Corona Commission will determine the epidemiological risk for the educational institutions per federal state. On the basis of this classification, the Education Directorate determines the risk level for the federal state in agreement with the central office by ordinance. The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location."    *Vorarlberg*  In its meeting on October 14th, 2021, the Corona Commission determined that the schools in Vorarlberg will remain in risk level 1 .    Test and mask requirement:  Schoolchildren: There is no MNS requirement in the entire school building and there is no longer any compulsory test. However, antigen tests can still be carried out voluntarily. These are confirmed by the school in the sticker pass.  Teaching and administrative staff: There is no MNS obligation in the entire school building. For staff who have not been vaccinated / have not recovered, an external PCR test must still be submitted once a week; further antigen tests must be carried out at the school. Vaccinated and convalescents can voluntarily test themselves with antigen tests.  External persons must present a 3-G certificate and wear MNS during their entire stay at the school.     Arrangement of compulsory tests and masks:  If suspected cases arise during the voluntary antigen tests or during tests outside the school, all schools have the option of ordering a temporary test or mask compulsory for individual classes or the entire school for a maximum of one week . Such an arrangement requires the approval of the Education Directorate.    *Measures for the entire federal state of Styria*  From September 30, 2021 (until July 8, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    In order to minimize the risk of infection, the provider must implement the hygiene concepts and guidelines of the State of Styria, which include, in particular, requirements for ventilating, cleaning and disinfecting rooms as well as general hygiene measures for children, staff, external persons and accompanying persons.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  External persons must wear an FFP2 mask in the facility.  A valid Corona test pass (documentation issued by the school on the evidence provided of a low epidemiological risk) is required to care for school-age children in after-school care centers. If no corona test pass can be presented, 3-G proof must be provided when entering the facility.    *Carinthia*  Additional measures in music schools apply to Carinthia.    Measures for the entire federal state of Carinthia  From September 13, 2021 (until February 13, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    The 3-G rule applies when entering child education and care facilities, as well as day-care centers and when staying in closed rooms in these facilities. If this is not provided, an MNS must be worn.  The provider of a facility must implement the requirements of the COVID-19 guidelines for child education and care facilities.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  The 3-G certificate is a prerequisite for caring for children in after-school care centers. If this cannot be achieved, the child has to wear an MNS.    *Measures for the entire federal state of Styria*  From September 30, 2021 (until July 8, 2022), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in child education and care facilities:    In order to minimize the risk of infection, the provider must implement the hygiene concepts and guidelines of the State of Styria, which include, in particular, requirements for ventilating, cleaning and disinfecting rooms as well as general hygiene measures for children, staff, external persons and accompanying persons.  Activities should be relocated to the open where this appears educationally sensible and organizationally possible.  External persons must wear an FFP2 mask in the facility.  A valid Corona test pass (documentation issued by the school on the evidence provided of a low epidemiological risk) is required to care for school-age children in after-school care centers. If no corona test pass can be presented, 3-G proof must be provided when entering the facility.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/i1aIC - Vorarlberg  https://archive.vn/tfL5J - Carinthia  https://archive.vn/vhzaV#selection-809.0-809.28 - Risk levels in Upper Austria  https://archive.vn/77eIK - COVID-19 agricultural school ordinance 2021/22 applies to Salzburg   https://archive.vn/Jmj3m - Styria  https://archive.vn/cN2uW - Vienna  https://archive.vn/dAqZ5 - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/v9L39 - Good starting conditions for the winter semester 2021/22 - 80 percent of the students vaccinated  https://archive.vn/fmtyw - Coronavirus - Current Measures

The responsible education directorate then informs the schools. Defined framework conditions also enable flexible measures to be taken at the school location. Customer areas  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores.   When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services may only let in customers if they can present 3-G evidence. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    At work  Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.  The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.  By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    Leisure, sport and culture    leisure  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:     Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks  Baths and facilities   Dance schools  Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos  Show mines  Facilities for the practice of prostitution  Indoor playgrounds  Paintball systems  Museum railways  Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens  The following applies in this area:    Customers must show a 3-G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.  Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    Culture  Unvaccinated persons must wear an FFP2 mask in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives.  For cultural institutions in which mainly get-togethers take place, such as theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.  Sports  The 3-G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   All sports are permitted, and contact sports are again possible.  Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.  There are detailed regulations for the exercise of sports by top athletes.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/dAqZ5 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/G1slX [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

At work   â¢  Workplaces may only be entered by teachers who are in direct contact with students, owners, operators and employees with direct customer contact, persons who are active in dealing with parties in administrative authorities and administrative courts if they are in contact with students, with customers and with parties wear a mask in closed rooms unless the risk of infection is minimized by other suitable protective measures.   â¢  The obligation to wear a mask does not apply if the persons present a 3-G certificate.   â¢  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.   â¢  By agreement between employers and employees, stricter rules for wearing a mask, an FFP2 mask without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard can be made in addition to the arrangements made for wearing a mask.    Customer areas   â¢  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores.    â¢  When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who have not been vaccinated or have recovered must wear an FFP2 mask.   â¢  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services may only let in customers if they can present 3-G evidence. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    3-G rule  The 3-G rule applies in the following areas:     â¢  gastronomy   â¢  Body-hugging services   â¢  Hotel and lodging   â¢  Leisure facilities (e.g. dance schools, zoos)   â¢  Cultural establishments    â¢  Non-public sports facilities   â¢  Meetings (from a number of participants of more than 100 people)   â¢  Trade and consumer fairs, congresses   â¢  Coaches and excursion boats    In addition, the 3G rule continues to apply in the following areas and for the following people:    In the provision of mobile care and support services   â¢  For visitors and employees of retirement and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled   â¢  For residents for new admission in old people's and nursing homes as well as inpatient residential facilities for the disabled   â¢  For visitors and employees of hospitals or health resorts   â¢  For employees from other locations where health services are provided.    The following applies as evidence of a low epidemiological risk:   â¢  Evidence of negative testing for SARS-CoV-2   â¢  Medical confirmation of a past infection   â¢  Separation notice   â¢  Vaccination certificate   â¢  Proof of neutralizing antibodies    The certificates for vaccinated, recovered and tested persons are on an equal footing, but differ in their validity period    Sources:  https://archive.vn/3dN2m [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/ZM5VV [Coronavirus - Current Measures]

At work [please note these guidelines include some which will be introduced from 1 November onwards]   â¢  Employees, owners and operators are only allowed to enter workplaces where physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out if they have a 3G certificate. Contacts within the meaning of the first sentence do not include a maximum of two physical contacts per day that take place outdoors and each do not last longer than 15 minutes.   â¢  Up to and including November 14th, employees, owners and operators who do not provide a 3G certificate are required to wear an FFP2 mask. From November 15th, a workplace may only be entered with valid 3G proof without exception.   â¢  The owner of a place of work with more than 51 employees must appoint a COVID-19 officer and develop and implement a COVID-19 prevention concept.   â¢  With regard to the wearing of a mask and the submission of evidence of a low epidemiological risk, stricter regulations that go beyond this ordinance can be provided in justified cases.    Customer areas   â¢  An FFP2 mask must be worn in everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and in grocery stores (including sales outlets of food producers and petrol stations with affiliated sales outlets for groceries).    â¢  When entering and driving in other customer areas as well as the connecting structures of structurally connected operating facilities (e.g. shopping centers, market halls), customers who do not provide 3G proof must wear an FFP2 mask.   â¢  The operator of business premises for the use of body-friendly services is only allowed to let customers in if they can present a 3G certificate. The customer must have this proof available for the duration of the stay.    Leisure, sport and culture    *Leisure*  Leisure facilities are businesses and facilities that serve entertainment, amusement or recreation. Leisure facilities are in particular:    â¢  Fairgrounds, amusement and amusement parks   â¢  Baths   â¢  Dance schools   â¢  Betting offices, slot machines, amusement arcades and casinos   â¢  Show mines   â¢  Facilities for the practice of prostitution   â¢  Indoor playgrounds   â¢  Paintball systems   â¢  Museum railways   â¢  Animal parks, zoos and botanical gardens    The following applies in this area:   â¢  Customers must show a 3G certificate, which must be kept available for the duration of their stay.   â¢  Every leisure company must create a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.    *Culture*  In museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, people who do not provide 3G proof must wear an FFP2 mask.  For cultural institutions in which mainly get-togethers take place, such as theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, a 3G certificate, a COVID-19 officer and a prevention concept are required.    *Sports*  The 3G rule applies to sports facilities. The proof must be kept ready for the duration of the stay.   Operators of non-public sports facilities must create a Covid-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.    Top athletes:  When top athletes practice sports, the responsible doctor must develop a COVID-19 prevention concept and monitor compliance with it on an ongoing basis.  Top athletes have to show a 3G certificate for training and competitions if physical contact with other people cannot be ruled out.  If a SARS-CoV-2 infection becomes known to an athlete, supervisor or trainer, all athletes, supervisors and trainers must undergo a molecular biological test or an antigen test for the presence of a SARS-CoV- 2 to undergo infection.    Gastronomy and accommodation    *Gastronomy*  When visiting a restaurant, the following rules must be observed:   â¢  3-G rule in catering establishments.   â¢  2.5G proof for establishments in the hospitality industry in which an increased mix and interaction of customers is to be expected, such as discos, clubs, aprÃ¨s-ski bars and dance halls in particular.    The operators of catering establishments must also ensure the following:   â¢  Self-service buffets can be operated subject to hygiene requirements.   â¢  Every catering business must create a prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.   â¢  Mandatory collection of customer data.   â¢  The 3-G rule does not apply to the pick-up of food and drinks, as well as snack bars and catering stands. Customers have to wear a mask in closed rooms.    *Night gastronomy*  Access to night-time catering, establishments in the hospitality industry in which an increased mix and interaction of customers is to be expected, such as discotheques, clubs, aprÃ¨s-ski bars and dance halls, is for vaccinated and convalescent people, as well as people with current negative PCR- Test result (max. 72 hours old) possible (2.5G proof).    *Accommodation*  The accommodation establishments are allowed to reopen under Covid conditions. To do this, the operators must: draw up a COVID-19 prevention concept and appoint a Covid-19 officer.   â¢  The 3G rule applies when entering for the first time. If the validity expires during the stay, a new proof must be provided.   â¢  For the use of the culinary offer in hotels and accommodation establishments, the regulations of the catering trade apply. The 3G rule must be observed for the use of gastronomy, wellness and fitness offers.   â¢  Mandatory collection of customer data.   â¢  Supervised camping or caravan sites, shelters and cabin ships are also considered to be accommodation facilities.    Sources:  https://archive.vn/vgVms - Nationwide Measures  https://archive.vn/nmP8T - Coronavirus - Current Measures

Events : Events from 100 people are notifiable to the district administrative authority and from 500 people require approval. In addition, if there are 100 or more participants, a prevention concept must be drawn up and implemented, and a: e  COVID-19 officer : r must be appointed. At meetings, the contact details of the participants must be collected.  The following applies to visitors:  â  When entering meetings with more than 25 participants, the 3-G rule applies.  â  People who are likely to stay at the relevant location for more than 15 minutes are obliged to provide their contact details for the purpose of tracking contact persons (registration obligation).    From Nationwide measures  In general:  In principle, there are no longer any maximum limits and capacity restrictions.  There is no longer a mask requirement at events.  Meetings with more than 25 participants are only permitted on the condition that the person responsible for the meeting only allows the participants to enter if they can provide proof of 3G.  Meetings of 100 people or more are notifiable. The participants have to show a 3G certificate, which has to be checked by the person responsible. He must also develop and implement a prevention concept and appoint a COVID-19 officer.  Meetings of 500 people or more must be approved. The 3-G rule also applies here. A prevention concept and the appointment of a COVID-19 officer is required.    Sources:   https://archive.vn/G1slX#selection-1637.0-1727.195 [Coronavirus - Current Measures]  https://archive.vn/dAqZ5 [Nationwide measures]

"The 3-G rule applies to gatherings of 25 or more people." Clearance and mouth and nose protection  There is no minimum distance of one meter from other people. In all places where the 3-G rule applies, there is no mask requirement. This also applies to employees in those areas in which a 3-G certificate is intended.  In everyday shops such as banks, post offices, pharmacies, drugstores and grocery stores, an FFP2 mask must be worn again instead of the previous MNS wearing obligation.  In addition, the wearing of an FFP2 mask in trade and cultural institutions becomes an obligation for unvaccinated people. Wearing an FFP2 mask is recommended for people who have been vaccinated.  Children up to the age of 6 do not have to wear an FFP2 mask or an MNS. Children from the age of 6 up to the age of 14 are also allowed to wear an MNS. Pregnant women are also allowed to wear an MNS.    2nd amendment to the 2nd COVID-19 - Measures Ordinance  Wearing an FFP 2 mask is compulsory in food retailing, including sales outlets of food producers and petrol stations with associated sales outlets for food, pharmacies, banks, post offices and public transport.  â¢For those who have not been vaccinated or who have not recovered It is compulsory for people to wear an FFP 2 mask in the entire trade, the day-care facilities in care for the elderly and in the disabled area, as well as cultural facilities (museums, libraries, theaters, cinemas, etc.).    Mask requirement in Vienna    In Vienna, the mask requirement applies in museums, art halls and cultural exhibition halls, libraries, libraries and archives, theaters, cinemas, variety theaters, cabarets, concert halls and arenas, as well as institutions for religious practice.    Sources:   https://archive.vn/dAqZ5#selection-1711.0-1711.39 [Nationwide measures]  https://archive.vn/G1slX#selection-1537.0-1601.180 [Coronavirus - Current Measures]  https://archive.vn/XEvAR [Vienna]

Measures for the entire state of Salzburg  From October 18, 2021, additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19:  â¢ In addition to the FFP2 mask requirement in public pharmacies, food retailers, banks, and post offices, there is still an FFP2 mask requirement without an exhalation valve or a mask with at least an equivalent standardized standard  for all customers in the  customer areas of business premises in closed rooms and in connecting structures that are structurally connected Business premises (e.g. shopping centers, market halls).  â¢ The FFP2 mask requirement also applies to body-hugging services and to all cultural institutions.  â¢ Employees in retail, body-friendly services and cultural institutions are exempt from this.    Source: https://archive.vn/tYjaF [Measures for the entire state of Salzburg]

Measures for the entire federal state of Carinthia  From October 18, 2021 (until December 31, 2021), additional measures will apply to prevent the spread of COVID-19 in inpatient retirement homes and care facilities:    Visitors are only permitted to enter stationary residential and care facilities for the elderly if they can present 2G evidence or a negative PCR test, the acceptance of which is not older than 72 hours.     In cases that are particularly worthy of consideration, in which visitors cannot show 2G evidence or a negative PCR test, a SARS-CoV-2 antigen test can be carried out under the supervision of a person authorized to do so by the operator of a nursing home. The negative test result must be kept available for the duration of the stay. This also applies to external service providers when there is contact with residents.    Employees may only enter inpatient residential and care facilities for the elderly if they can present proof of 2G or a weekly negative PCR test, the acceptance of which is not older than 72 hours.    Source: https://archive.vn/lwufm [overview of current measures in Carinthia]

Quote: Citizens and legal residents of Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Canada, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland, Israel, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Qatar, Russia, Serbia, Singapore, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Turkey, the UAE, the UK, and the US are allowed to enter by air without the previously required special permission if they meet the following conditions:  - All passengers of 18 years and older must possess official documentation (i.e., COVID Passport) demonstrating that they have either been fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19. Additionally, a negative result from a PCR test not older than 72 hours is required.  - All passengers between 1 and 18 years of age must possess a negative result from a PCR test not older than 72 hours.  - No such documents are required for infants aged less than one year.    Returning Azerbaijani nationals require only a negative result from a PCR test within 72 hours prior to the flight.     Land and maritime borders remain closed, air travel is the only option to enter. A limited number of commercial and charter flights are operating to and from selected destinations. Passengers on domestic flights are no longer required to provide a test, but those flying into Baku's Heydar Aliyev International Airport (GYD) will undergo PCR tests upon arrival."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211012222802/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/528426/azerbaijan-government-to-ease-certain-covid-19-related-restrictions-effective-oct-1-update-38

All workplaces are allowed to be open now, including previously closed discos and nightclubs. However, concerning discos and nightclubs, they are only allowed to be opened provided that the Covid Safe Ticket is used and adequate air quality and ventilation is provided in line with stricter guidelines.     The Covid Safe Ticket is proof of full vaccination, of a recent negative PCR test or of a recovery certificate. Current economic measures in place have been extended to December 31, 2021. The five socio-economic support measures that are extended until December 31, 2021 are as follows: Temporary unemployment due to force majeure for all sectors, The simple crisis gateway right for all sectors from a loss of 65% of turnover, A monthly bonus of 25 euros for beneficiaries of integration income, a GRAPA or an ARR Financial support for rail operators (people and freight) and Maintaining the VAT rate at 6% on hydroalcoholic gel and masks    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003171205/https://www.premier.be/fr/prolongation-ciblee-des-mesures-de-soutien-economique-jusquau-31-decembre-2021

Starting October 26, the mask requirement now applies uniformly in all of Belgium. It is required in the following situations; in public transportation and in medical and non-medical contact occupations, stores and shopping malls; health care facilities; areas accessible to the public in companies, public buildings, court buildings; establishments for cultural, festive, sporting and recreational activities, including theaters, concert halls, cinemas, museums, indoor theme and amusement parks, indoor fitness centers and sports centers; libraries, toy and game libraries and media libraries; worship centers.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104151557/https://www.commissioner.brussels/en/updates-covid-19/item/885-uniform-measures-in-belgium

Until October 31, the Republic of Bulgaria will be conducting face-to-face group classes in language centres, educational centres and other training centres and schools with a limit of 10 per room and mandatory physical distancing. Other precautions such as mask wearing is in place.  https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

Kindergartens and nurseries are open. Schools in certain âred COVID-19 areasâ in Bulgaria, including Sofia, and all universities in the country are on remote learning.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101214710/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Workplaces are to hold employees in remote form when possible, and will allow 50% of regular staff in the office. There will be working hours established from 7.30 until 10 oâclock when possible. Workers are required to maintain physical distance and wear masks.   https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

Capacity reductions, reduced operating hours, social distancing requirements, and mandates requiring facemasks in all enclosed public spaces are in effect through Oct. 30 at open-air and enclosed retail and market spaces, catering facilities, cultural venues, convention centers, entertainment venues, and other establishments. Some restrictions can be waived if all persons present are vaccinated.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101215018/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/533771/bulgaria-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-entry-restrictions-as-of-oct-12-easing-entry-controls-for-uk-travelers-update-36

Holding congress-conference events, seminars, training and other events are allowed at 30% capacity while participants maintain physical distance and wear masks. Team-building events are suspended/ competitions and exams are allowed at 30% capacity, not exceeding 30 participants. Mass events (festivals, fairs etc.) are suspended. Cinemas, theaters, circus and concerts are allowed at 50% while maintaining physical distance and face masks. Museums and galleries allowed one person per 8 sq. M. Visits to centres, schools and other sites for dance and music art are allowed at 30% capacity and not more than 10 people in premises. Sports games allowed without an audience, but if outside, at 30% capacity. Private character events allowed with 30 people indoors and 60 outdoors.   https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

Mass events are suspended.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211101215018/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/533771/bulgaria-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-entry-restrictions-as-of-oct-12-easing-entry-controls-for-uk-travelers-update-36

Indoor private events may not exceed 30 persons, while outdoor private events may not surpass 60 persons. Starting Oct. 21, individuals must possess a "green certificate" to engage in any indoor activities, including visiting restaurants, cinemas, gyms, and shopping malls. A green certificate constitutes proof of vaccination, recent recovery, or a recent negative test; the exact testing requirements remain unclear.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211102002818/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/536776/bulgaria-authorities-to-tighten-domestic-covid-19-restrictions-from-oct-21-update-37

Through November 30, the EU has categorized countries into different coloured zones based on epidemiological rate of infection resonating to certain travel restrictions. These include details on testing, quarantine, and safety measures.  https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

Authorities in Bulgaria have amended international entry restrictions imposed to combat the spread of COVID-19. As of Oct. 12, entry is permitted for UK travelers arriving from the UK, a European Union member state, the European Economic Area, or Switzerland provided they present a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival, as well as a certificate of COVID-19 vaccination or recovery; travelers that do not possess a certificate indicating COVID-19 vaccination or recovery may enter Bulgaria but must self-isolate for 10 days upon arrival.    Authorities have also moved France, Monaco, Portugal, Cyprus, and Iceland into the green list of countries while moving Malaysia, Eswatini, Iran, Macedonia, Kosovo, Kazakhstan, the U.S., and Ireland to the orange list of countries. Barbados, Antigua and Barbuda, Romania, Estonia, Latvia, Slovakia, and Singapore are to be considered red-list countries from Oct. 13.    Authorities in Bulgaria classify countries as green, orange, or red based on local disease activity and accordingly apply differing entry restrictions. Travelers from green and orange countries can enter upon presenting a valid EU Digital COVID certificate or similar document confirming vaccination against COVID-19, recovery from COVID-19, or a recent negative test for the disease. Travelers without such documentation must isolate for 10 days on arrival, though isolation can be ended early following receipt of a negative result from a COVID-19 test taken within 24 hours after arrival.    Travel from red countries is permitted for EU citizens, their families, and persons traveling for selected essential purposes only. Permitted travelers from red countries must present a valid EU Digital COVID certificate or similar document indicating vaccination against or recovery from COVID-19, in addition to a negative result from a PCR test taken no more than 72 hours prior to arrival and certified by a valid EU Digital COVID certificate or similar document. Limited categories of travelers are permitted to enter by only satisfying the PCR test requirement, but must self-isolate for 10 days on arrival.      Citizens and residents of Romania, Turkey, Greece, Serbia, and North Macedonia who also travel daily or weekly to Bulgaria for work or study may enter the country without restrictions; these travelers do not need to show COVID-19-related documentation to enter Bulgaria. The same rules apply to Bulgarian citizens and residents who travel daily or weekly for work or study to these five neighboring countries. Freight transporters and aircraft crews are also exempt from the documentation requirement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101215018/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/533771/bulgaria-authorities-amend-covid-19-related-entry-restrictions-as-of-oct-12-easing-entry-controls-for-uk-travelers-update-36

PCR testing is widely available at sites across the country, including hospitals and private laboratories. Currently 100 hospitals and laboratories in Bulgaria are officially accredited by the Ministry of Health. A full list is published in Health Order ? ??-01-774/16.09.2021 ?. The fee is generally approximately $100 and is fully covered by . It is preferable, to make an appointment by phone as most of the hospitals have specific time slots during which citizens can get tested. Tests results can be checked online but originals are usually stamped and collected in person.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211101214710/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Face masks must be worn indoors at all times and outdoors if unable to maintain a distance of 1.5 m.   https://archive.vn/Rtpk9

All persons must wear a mask that covers their mouth and nose in all indoor public spaces as well as in open public spaces where there is a crowd of people and it is not possible to observe a physical distance of 1.5 m. Scarves or substitute face coverings are no longer allowed in place of a mask. All persons must cover their mouth and nose with a mask or covering on all public transportation including while in railway, bus and metro stations, and airports etc.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211101214710/https://bg.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

- Entry into the Republic of Belarus through a land border for foreign citizens has been suspended. There is a narrow list of concessions, including for holders of permanent/temporary residency - you should check the State Border Committee website for details.  - Foreign arrivals above the age of six, without vaccine certification must have a medical PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction) certificate showing a negative coronavirus test result, issued no later than 72 hours before entry. This requirement does not apply to holders of permanent or temporary residency in Belarus.   - Arrivals who are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 are not required to self-isolate for 7 days or produce a negative PCR test certificate provided the second dose was administered more than 1 but less than 12 months before arrival.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211101233747/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belarus/entry-requirements

The use of protective face mask is mandatory for all persons over twelve (12) years old, indoors where there are more than one person and outdoors where there are more than two persons with the exception of the cases specified by the guidelines issued by the Ministry of Health.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211016231253/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/08102021_Decree%20No%2037_EN.pdf

) The guidelines of the Ministry of Health and the Ministry of Labour shall apply to  visitors and employees of nursing homes and other closed settings such as care for the  elderly units and hostels for vulnerable groups and persons aged 12 and above should  hold either a negative Covid-19 laboratory test performed within 72 hours, or a certificate  of vaccination against Covid-19 for at least one dose and provided that three weeks have  elapsed after the date of vaccination or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 and  provided that a period of six months has not elapsed since the date of the initial positive  diagnosis, or an EU Digital COVID Certificate of vaccination or recovery  https://web.archive.org/web/20211016231253/https://www.pio.gov.cy/coronavirus/uploads/08102021_Decree%20No%2037_EN.pdf
All schools open but hygiene and sanitation measures such as face mask-wearing still in place to limit the spread of coronavirus.  https://archive.ph/YoK26

Shopping centres, farmers markets, restaurants and bars are open, but strict hygiene and sanitation measures remain in place. Workplaces such as banks and insurance companies are open, but customers are encouraged to use online, telephone or written service options rather than in-person services where possible. Post offices also open, but operating at reduced hours and capacity.   https://archive.ph/dQFtG  https://archive.ph/1tc8Z  https://archive.ph/zhAna  https://archive.ph/Lb4mM  https://archive.ph/zyxYq

Public and private events can take place with a limit of 2000 participants outdoors and 1000 people indoors. If more than 20 people are present at the event, all those over 6 years of age must prove upon arrival that they satisfy one of the conditions listed on the archived webpage. A maximum of 20 people can meet without complying with these conditions. The organizers of mass events, which are expected to be attended by more than 1,000 people (daily), must notify the local relevant regional hygiene station no later than 5 days before the start of the event.  https://archive.ph/hV07a

Public transport open but with mask-wearing requirements. It is ordered to wear respiratory protective equipment with an efficiency of at least 94% in all means of public transport.   https://archive.ph/mv6yP
No requirement to stay at home, unless self-isolating or suspect close contact of a positive case as per government advice.   https://archive.ph/UsXAD
Currently no restrictions on free movement within the country.   https://archive.ph/8sLBD

Depending on level of coronavirus in country travellers are arriving from, different entry rules apply. These vary according to the level of risk (green, orange, red and dark red countries) and may involve self-isolation/quarantine, as well as PCR testing. Third-country nationals not on the list of countries with a low risk of COVID-19 are still currently prohibited from entering. There is also a ban on free movement for people arriving from abroad.   https://archive.ph/npWd2  https://archive.ph/9omJW  https://archive.ph/O6PbG

Employees, who have been quarantined, are entitled to a wage compensation of 60% of their reduced average earnings during the first 14 days. From the 15th calendar day, the sickness insurance benefit starts, paid by the employee's local District Social Security Administration. As a further incentive for the employees, a special benefit that goes above the Labour Code regulations - the "Izolacka"- has been created, a extraordinary benefit amounting up to CZK 370 a day of quarantine/isolation additionally to the wage compensation. Its main purpose is preventing the virus spread among employees and (as early as possible) eliminating an income fall.  https://archive.ph/GnvCu
Comprehensive and regularly up-dated official government coronavirus website.   https://archive.ph/Ywcda

PCR tests widely available and free of charge if indicated (ie. symptoms or possible contact with positive case). If PCR test not indicated, options to self-pay for test or may be covered by health insurance.  https://archive.ph/zqM0k
No change, comprehensive contact tracing appears to be continuing.   https://archive.ph/27Hz4

It is ordered to wear respiratory protective equipment with an efficiency of at least 94% in all interiors of buildings, with a few exceptions. It is also necessary to wear the given respiratory protection outdoors, if there is an accumulation of persons in the given area (concerts, sports matches, etc.) and several other situations. The obligation to wear a respiratory protective device with an efficiency of at least 94% does not apply during exercise and training. Face coverings are mandatory on public transport.   https://archive.ph/YTwA6  https://archive.ph/FED3x

Vaccines widely available and booster vaccines now taking place 6 months after the second dose (or 6 months after the first dose for the Janssen vaccine). The Danish travel restrictions classify all countries and regions into four colour categories: green, yellow, orange and red. These categories determine which rules apply to you.     People coming in from countries in the red zone have the strictest guidelines requiring: a test required prior to boarding aircraft, test and isolation required after entry, with foreigners requiring a worthy purpose for entry to Denmark, and to take test prior to entry to Denmark (EU Digital COVID Certificate)    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211005165127/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/categorization-of-countries

The Danish travel restrictions classify all countries and regions into four colour categories: green, yellow, orange and red. These categories determine which rules apply to you.     People coming in from countries in the red zone have the strictest guidelines requiring: a test required prior to boarding aircraft, test and isolation required after entry, with foreigners requiring a worthy purpose for entry to Denmark, and to take test prior to entry to Denmark (EU Digital COVID Certificate)    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211005165127/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations/entry-into-denmark/categorization-of-countries

There are new entry requirements in Denmark which came into effect on October 25.    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents in EU/Schengen or an OECD-country*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country without testing or self-isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark from an EU/Schengen country or within 24 hours after arrival  2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark from a EU/Schengen country with testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival  3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211030131742/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

Rules were updated on November 3    1) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents coming in EU/Schengen can enter Denmark. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test before entering Denmark  or within 24 hours after arrival    2) Fully vaccinated or previously infected residents from COVID-19 risk countries*, can enter Denmark without testing and without self isolating. Those who are not fully vaccinated or previously infected you must take a negative test within 24 hours after arrival    3) People coming in from high risk countries have to get tested and also self isolate. However, those who are previously infected or fully vaccinated and have permanent residence or a residence permit in an EU-, Schengen- or OECD-country* or one of the COVID-19 risk countries/regions are exempted. Those with a valid certificate of vaccination are also exempted      Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211104165021/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/travel-rules/categorization-of-countries

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. You are also advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when you visit the hospital. However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves. Face masks may be removed if the wearer experience a severe discomfort, such as difficulty breathing.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211005163829/https://en.coronasmitte.dk/rules-and-regulations

The Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Social Affairs and Health have examined the grounds for the validity of the national telework recommendation and propose that the telework recommendation end on 15 October. However, the Department of Health and Welfare estimates recommends the extension of the telework recommendation one month onwards, until October 31. However, this is not necessary in areas that are considered low-risk in terms of Covid 19 transmission rates. At present, there is no assembly restriction decisions issued by the regional government agency in any region. Municipalities can decide on restrictions on gatherings in their areas. However, in areas where there is no existing restriction on gatherings, the organization of events and occasions requires that their safety be ensured in accordance with the hygiene requirements laid down in Article 58c of the Communicable Diseases Act. Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211003182039/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017163157/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory. The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. It has been approved by Parliament and is now awaiting confirmation by the President    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210923115605/https://www.kela.fi/web/en/unemployment-benefit-corona

The amendment to the unemployment benefit legislation will be extended until 30 November 2021. Those laid off temporarily and the lay-off started on or after 16 March 2020, are eligible for an unemployment benefit even if they are studying. This is a temporary change that will be effective until 31 December 2021. The use of facemasks is recommended in all parts of the country    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210923121225/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

The Finnish Institute of Health recommends the use of facemasks especially in public indoor spaces where many people are in close proximity to each other as well as those who are on their way to get tested for the coronavirus, and those who are waiting for the results of a test, if there is an urgent reason to go outside the home. Those over the age of 12 who have not received two doses of COVID-19 vaccine or who have not had a COVID-19 infection within the past six months are also specially recommended to use the facemasks.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211017165642/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/transmission-and-protection-coronavirus/recommendation-on-the-use-of-face-masks-for-citizens

No change in policy, entry to France remains controlled depending on the vaccination status, reason for traveling, and country of traveler origin. Origin countries are categorised as Green/Orange/Red depending on Covid-19 prevalence, and as of 11/5 are:     - "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Canada, Chile, comoros, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Kuwait, Lebanon, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, the United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu.  - "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which there is active circulation of the virus in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories.  - "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed with the presence of variants of concern. These are: Afghanistan, Brazil, Costa Rica, Cuba, Georgia, Moldova, Montenegro, Pakistan, Russia, Serbia, Suriname and Turkey.    Travelers from Green list countries aged twelve years or older are not subject to the regime of compelling reasons, but are required to present:    - proof of having received all the doses prescribed for one of the vaccines approved by the European Medicines Agency  - or the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 72 hours before departure.  - or a recovery certificate dating back more than eleven days and less than six months (this document is issued to the person who has been contaminated by Covid-19 on presentation of a positive result in an RT-PCR screening examination or an antigen test).    A reinforced regimen is in place for the United Kingdom, with a test initially required (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours for unvaccinated people.    For travelers from Orange list countries:    Unvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories must present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test performed less than 72 hours or an antigen test (TAG) performed less than 48 hours before the flight. They may be subject to a random antigen test upon arrival.  Vaccinated travellers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime.  Unvaccinated travellers are subject to the regime of compelling reasons and will have to undertake self-isolation for 7 days. The list of compelling reasons is specified in thetravel and travel certificate issued by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.    For travel from Red list countries:   Unvaccinated travellers from these countries/territories:  - are subject to the regime of compelling reasons, the list of which is specified in the travel and travel certificate drawn up by the Ministry of the Interior. Under this list, the following may enter France: the French, their spouses and children, nationals of the European area as well as their spouses and children having their main residence in France or who join, in transit through France, their main residence in a country of the European area or the country of which they are nationals.  - must present at boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight.  - will be subject to a mandatory antigen test upon arrival.  - will be subject to a mandatory 10-day quarantine,controlled by the security forces.    Those travelers from countries that must demonstrate a "compelling reason" may be denied entry if their journey does not meet the requirements deailed at https://web.archive.org/web/20211102144014/https://www.interieur.gouv.fr/Actualites/L-actu-du-Ministere/Attestation-de-deplacement-et-de-voyage     https://web.archive.org/web/20211105173602/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

RT-PCR and lateral flow tests remain generally available, but the cost of such tests are no longer universally covered by health insurance as of 15 October.     Prime Minister Jean Castex announced that "It is no longer legitimate to pay excessively for comfort tests at taxpayers' expense. But tests will continue to be reimbursed on medical grounds, either without a prescription for people already vaccinated or on prescription for others. We also want to keep it free for minors. The logic is to reimburse tests related to truly medical reasons, and to continue to encourage vaccination."    Testing costs will be covered by insurance for people:     - having a complete vaccination schedule (or a contraindication to vaccination)  - minors  - identified for "contact tracing" by the Health Insurance agency  - during collective screening campaigns (ARS, schools, etc.)  - symptomatic on medical prescription  - with a recovery certificate of less than six months    Tests required to obtain a Health Pass become chargeable as of 15 October.     - https://web.archive.org/web/20211020113443/https://www.gouvernement.fr/fin-de-la-gratuite-systematique-des-tests-covid-19

"In indoor public spaces (shops, offices, schools etc) and on public transport you must wear a mask that covers your nose and mouth. You donât need to wear a mask in places where a health pass is required (although local authorities may review this). If you are outside you do not need to wear a mask except in places where social distancing is not possible (queues, open-air markets, railway stations, etc.)."    Masks are also required in schools, although this requirement will be relaxed on 4 October if the COVID-19 incidence rate is <50 per 100,000 inhabitants within a Department for a period of 5 days. https://web.archive.org/web/20211011051127/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Masks are required in many public places where physical distancing of 2m cannot be maintained, although notably is not required when a person enters a venue or event that requires a Health Pass for admission. Stricter restrictions may be required in Departments where Covid-19 incidence rate is higher than the threshold of 50 per 100,000 inhabitants - https://web.archive.org/web/20211015144634/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

Vaccination is available to everyone aged 12 years and 2 months or older.     Vaccination is mandatory for the following groups from 15 September 2021:   - all staff (including administrative staff) of health institutions, medico-social institutions (EHPAD, USLD, autonomous residences, disability structures with or without accommodation and including non-medicalized), social institutions attached to a health institution (LHSS, LAM, CSAPA, CAARUD, CLAT, CEGGID);  - home helpers working with people affecting APA or PCH, in home services or as employees of individual employers;  s- taff of medical transport companies (including taxis under agreement);  - all professions in Book IV of the CSP, whether or not under agreement, and professions for the use of titles, as well as their employees (e.g. medical secretaries, dental assistants);  - all health students;  - SDIS-Firefighters (professionals and volunteers);  - occupational health service personnel.    Booster vaccines are recommended for people aged 65 and over, people with comorbidities that increase risk of severe forms of Covid-19. A vaccination booster campaign us underway to promote a third vaccination for residents of nursing homes and LTCU, people over 80, those at very high risk of severe Covid-19, and immunocompromised people.     Janssen, AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211011053023/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Pfizer-BioNTech booster vaccines are recommended for people who received their last vaccination 6 months ago, or 4 weeks after vaccination with the Janssen vaccine, for the following groups of people:    - People aged 12-17 who are immunocompromised or comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19    - People aged 18 to 64 who:   -- have been vaccinated with the Janssem vaccine  -- are living with compromised immune systems or comorbidities that increase the risk of severe forms of Covid-19, and those who live with them  -- health care professionals, home assistants, transport staff working with vulnerable people  -- firefighters    - people aged 65 or over     Janssen, AstraZeneca, Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are available.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211022163823/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

Land borders of Georgia are open from June 1, 2021 in line with a decision made by the Inter-Agency Coordination Council. Border crossing is currently permitted to citizens of EU member states and 40 countries   in addition, as well as to individuals with a permission of residence. They need to present the following at the border crossing: document evidencing a full cycle of vaccination and a negative result of PCR test obtained in the past 72 hours, or alternatively present only a negative PCR test result obtained 72 hours prior to the visit to Georgia and get a repeated PCR test on the 3rd day of their stay in Georgia at their own expense.  Ref: http://archive.today/2021.10.12-091850/https://stopcov.gov.ge/en/shezgudvebi

https://archive.is/7s8Uj  Greece will, starting on Saturday, begin a two-week test of lifting some pandemic restrictions in regions where coronavirus cases have been the highest â but for the most part, only vaccinated people will be able to enjoy the heightened freedom.

no policy change   At level 4 (red) of the Epidemiology Charter country incorporated the Regional Units Kavala, Imathia, Pieria and Pella , while extending a special, local, measures in Regional Units Haryana and Argolis , after re-evaluation of epidemiological data the Committee of Infectious Diseases and the National Committee for the Protection of Public Health against the Covid-19 coronavirus in the context of the epidemiological surveillance of the country by Regional Unit and Municipality on a weekly basis.    At the same time, level 3 (orange) includes the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion , as well as the Municipality of Ikaria .    It is reminded that the measures in force are the following:    Traffic ban from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in stores of health interest and entertainment.  The measures are valid from tomorrow, Friday 17 September at 06.00 until Friday 24 September at 6:00 .    It is also reminded that in these areas, as well as in the whole territory, it is forbidden to hold any form of events in exchange for any form of exchange, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space . The administrative fine in case of violation amounts from 50,000 to 200,000 euros for the lessee or concessionaire of the private, non-professional space, in which the said event took place or takes place.    /web/20210919221253/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-kavala-imathia-pieria-kai-pella

All unvaccinated people in Greece from Monday, September 13, will be allowed to board all means of transport for domestic travel between regions (airplanes, ferries, intercity trains and KTEL buses) only if they have a negative Covid-19 rapid antigen test result.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211022124338/https://news.gtp.gr/2021/09/13/covid-19-how-unvaccinated-greece-can-travel-by-land-air-sea-rules/

no policy change     Some regions continue with restrictions on activities:  Level 4 (red) of the Epidemiological Map of the country includes the Regional Units of Argolida and Evritania, while the validity of the special, local character, measures in the Regional Units of Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Heraklion, as well as in the Municipality of Ikaria are extended.    It is recalled that the measures in force are the following:  Curfew from 01:00 in the evening until 06:00 in the morning, with the exception of work and serious health reasons.  Prohibition of music around the clock in shops of sanitary interest and entertainment.  The measures are in effect from tomorrow, Friday, September 10 at 06.00 until Friday, September 16 at 6:00.  Also, it is reminded that both in these areas, as well as throughout the country, it is forbidden to conduct any form of events for any form of consideration, with the physical presence of a crowd of more than twenty (20) people in a private, non-professional space.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210911005856/https://www.civilprotection.gr/el/simantika-themata/sto-epipedo-4-toy-epidimiologikoy-harti-tis-horas-argolida-kai-eyrytania  https://web.archive.org/web/20210911002130/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

From 5 August, there are additional gathering restrictions in Sisimiut, Upernavik, Upernavik district and Aasiaat. A maximum of 20 persons may gather in these geographic areas, for both outdoor and indoor arrangements, events, and other public activities. Some public establishments may be required to limit access to fewer than 20 persons, depending on the size of their area. This is valid through 31 October.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315224140/https://blog.wego.com/greenland-travel-restrictions-and-quarantine-requirements/

Persons 12 years of age and older who travel out of Nuuk or Sisimiut to another place in Greenland, and who are not fully vaccinated, must go into quarantine for 14 days upon arrival to their destination, or go into quarantine until receiving a negative test result on a PCR test taken on the 5th day after departure from Nuuk or Sisimiut, at the earliest. This is valid through 30 November 2021.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211103045826/https://visitgreenland.com/corona-faq/#toggle-id-13-closed

In Denmark, a face mask or shield is required at the airport. A face mask or shield is not required when using public transportation. You are advised to wear a face mask or shield at test centres or when you visit the hospital.    However, some groups are exempt from the required use of face mask or shield. These include, for instance, children up to the age of 12, people with a decreased level of consciousness, or people with physical or mental impairments that make it impossible for them to remove the face mask or shield themselves.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210424102045/https://konzuliszolgalat.kormany.hu/europa-utazasi-tanacsok?dania

28 October 2021, guidelines issued for the reopening of venues operating for the purposes of live entertainment and nightclubs in a safe and controlled manner.    Guidelines are offered to assist with mitigation whilst COVID-19 is still circulating in our communities. Central to these guidelines is a commitment to adhering to best practice in infection prevention control measures which are necessary to protect individuals and society, as well as supporting our continued progress towards a full return to operation of our sector as the epidemiological situation allows.    The measures outlined in this document are intended to assist organisers by:  ? Limiting the possibility of a COVID-19 outbreak due to event operations and venue  management through Infection Prevention and Control measures;  ? Ensuring business continuity through resource planning and avoiding loss of key personnel  due to illness or being identified as close contacts while at work; and  ? Safeguarding against reputational damage through implementation of these measures.    These guidelines apply to venues operating for the purposes of live entertainment or nightclubs which  meet the following essential conditions:  Nightclubs/Premises covered by these guidelines must meet the following conditions:  - Must be the holder of a current and valid on licence or theatre licence.  - Must have been granted by the Court a special exemption order or occasional licence for  each occasion they intend to operate beyond normal licensing hours.  - Must comply with the conditions of the special exemption order, occasional licence, dance  licence and/or music and singing licences attaching to the premises.  - Must, on 22 October, have a designated performance area, stage or booth for performers  and will typically also have a specialist sound and lighting system.  - Must, on 22 October, have a designated dance floor or standing or seating area which are  specifically utilised only for the purposes of viewing a performance.  - Must generally cease operation at the end of the performance, having regard to normal  licensing arrangements.  - Events must be ticketed (electronic) to facilitate contact tracing. This will come into effect  on 29 October 2021.  - For live performances, up to 1,500 patrons may stand with the remaining members of the  audience sitting. Therefore, 100% seated capacity is permitted. For events with a  combination of seated and standing, capacity is subject to a maximum standing capacity of  1,500 and any additional capacity beyond 1,500 must be fully seated.    - For nightclubs no capacity limit applies1  .  - Bar and counter service may operate in nightclubs and live entertainment venues subject to  strict adherence to the following conditions:  o Patrons may only approach the bar to order, pay for or collect food/drinks;  o 1m social distancing in the queue and at the bar;  o Employee supervising the queue.     https://drive.google.com/file/d/1fpy4kE19Le2N_rGIxbmaMMfhmVkDBROJ/view?usp=sharing

From 22 October 2021, further restrictions will be lifted, including limits on numbers attending:    - Weddings  - Organised indoor and outdoor group events  - Religious or civil ceremonies  - Nightclubs and other hospitality can fully reopen with some restrictions in place.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211024162025/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/health/covid19/public_health_measures_for_covid19.html

Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210914071118/https://www.adnkronos.com/scuola-e-obbligo-green-pass-primo-giorno-regole-in-classe_2qTRFcm7k4wipUZEQDtKWe  http://web.archive.org/web/20211004161458/https://www.tgcom24.mediaset.it/skuola/universita-come-si-torna-in-facolta-le-regole-per-lanno-accademico-2021-22_39031586-202102k.shtml

The decree on the work of educational organizations in the 2021/2022 academic year during the Covid-19 pandemic was signed by the chief state sanitary doctor of Kazakhstan, Yerlan Kiyasov.  The decree says:  Allow training in the 2021/2022 academic year in a regular format in educational organizations of all forms of ownership and departmental affiliation.  Akims of regions, the cities of Almaty, Nur-Sultan, Shymkent, the Ministry of Education and Science of the Republic of Kazakhstan, heads of educational organizations of all forms of ownership and departmental affiliation to provide training in the 2021/2022 academic year in a regular format under the following conditions:  compliance with sanitary and anti-epidemic measures;  100% vaccination of teachers and staff (with the exception of persons with permanent medical contraindications who have recovered from Covid-19);  implementation of the Ashyq application at the entrance to the organization (registration by the QR code of teachers, staff, parents, visitors, students aged 18 and over);  observance of the mask regime;  provision of a sufficient number of recirculators, sanitizers, skin antiseptics, disinfectants and detergents;  increasing the frequency of cleaning and disinfection of premises;  compliance with the requirements for wet cleaning and disinfection of premises, for the mode of ventilation and disinfection of air in premises;  daily "input" filter (thermometry with a non-contact thermometer) for teachers, staff and students;  a ban on holding mass events (cultural, educational, extracurricular and parental meetings, and others);  a ban on holding events in organizations of preschool and secondary education with the unification of groups and classes;  the abolition of the office training system, with the exception of laboratory, practical classes;  separation of students in primary, middle and senior classes (taking into account the maximum opportunity for the time of the beginning of classes).  The document also spelled out the conditions for the introduction of quarantine in educational organizations :  when registering one case of Covid-19 in a class (group) - the class (group) is subject to isolation for home quarantine for 14 days;  when registering in a secondary education organization in one incubation period of cases of Covid-19 disease in more than 30% of classes of one shift - the change is subject to isolation for home quarantine for 14 days;  when registering in colleges, higher educational institutions in one incubation period of cases of Covid-19 in more than 30% of groups of one stream - the stream is subject to isolation for home quarantine for 14 days.  "The solution to the issue of introducing quarantine in the organization of secondary education, college, higher educational institution with the transfer to a distance learning format of all students - in agreement with the Committee of Sanitary and Epidemiological Control of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan," the resolution says.  It is not allowed to enter the organizations of preschool and secondary education, colleges, universities, including canteens and canteens:  persons with signs of a respiratory infection (cough, runny nose, body temperature above 37 degrees Celsius);  persons with "yellow" and "red" status when registering by QR-code;  teachers and staff who are not vaccinated against Covid-19 (with the exception of persons with permanent medical contraindications who have recovered from Covid-19).  It is noted that in education departments and educational organizations will be appointed responsible for the exchange of information on cases of Covid-19 disease and contacts among pupils, students, teachers and personnel of educational organizations.  In addition, the chief sanitary doctor allowed foreign students to enter the territory of Kazakhstan. They need to have a vaccination passport, as well as a certificate with a negative PCR test result.    https://archive.vn/m1MWC#selection-453.0-761.99

A wide variety of businesses â including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities â are open, in some cases subject to restrictions on hours of operation subject to capacity limitations. Nur-Sultan, Almaty (city only), Akmola, North Kazakhstan, and Pavlodar regions are classified as red zones. Additional restrictions in red zones include the following:    Health checkpoints are in place on roads approaching settlements where the daily incidence of COVID-19 exceeds 10 new infections per day.    Public transport is suspended on weekends and public holidays.    Freight transporters may not enter these regions without evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken within the preceding 72 hours; transporters who fail to produce such evidence will be placed in a quarantine facility for at least two days.    Operating hours have been reduced, and capacity restricted at restaurants, cafes, theaters, cinemas, shopping malls, and leisure facilities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105144653/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/537286/kazakhstan-authorities-ease-some-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-as-of-oct-20-update-48

Nationwide, authorities require residents to obtain a government-provided QR code via the Ashyq mobile application to visit government offices and certain public spaces, including leisure facilities, cultural venues, and entertainment establishments. Ashyq codes are also required to gain entry to international airports in Almaty and Nur-Sultan. Residents will have their app scanned at each establishment; each QR code scan will reveal a resident's color-coded risk rating:    Red - movement restricted to self-isolation regime    Yellow - movement partially restricted; essential trips to nearest pharmacy and grocery store permitted    Blue - no specific restrictions    Green - no specific restrictions, and the user has a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105144653/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/537286/kazakhstan-authorities-ease-some-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-as-of-oct-20-update-48

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes, in some cases.  As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk âRed Zones.â An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the âAshyqâ application system (please see further information on âAshyqâ in the Quarantine Information paragraph below).  Kazakhstanâs regions are empowered to take additional measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 as necessary, including erecting checkpoints to limit travel in and out of cities and oblasts.  Before pursuing domestic travel in Kazakhstan, we urge you to research whether checkpoints might be in place that could restrict your ability to travel.   For regional information please see this Kazakhstani âElectronic Governmentâ website.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105143702/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Nur-Sultan, Almaty (city only), Akmola, North Kazakhstan, and Pavlodar regions are classified as red zones. Additional restrictions in red zones include the following:    Health checkpoints are in place on roads approaching settlements where the daily incidence of COVID-19 exceeds 10 new infections per day.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105144653/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/537286/kazakhstan-authorities-ease-some-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-as-of-oct-20-update-48

Quote: "International Travel RestrictionsVisa-free travel remains suspended. Authorities have also suspended 72-hour visa-free stays for Chinese and Indian nationals. However, flights with several countries have resumed, including Belarus, Egypt, Germany, South Korea, Kyrgyzstan, the Netherlands, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, the United Arab Emirates (UAE), and Uzbekistan, though capacity is likely to be limited.    International arrivals must provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry into Kazakhstan or a vaccination certificate. This restriction does not apply to diplomats, aircrew, train crews, ship crews, and cross-border workers; however, freight truck drivers must provide a negative test. Returning Kazakh nationals who do not produce a negative test or vaccine certificate upon arrival will be tested and placed in quarantine for at least three days. All symptomatic individuals will be hospitalized, while asymptomatic individuals must self-isolate for a further 12 days."    https://web.archive.org/web/20211105144653/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/537286/kazakhstan-authorities-ease-some-covid-19-related-domestic-restrictions-as-of-oct-20-update-48
